awd_titl_txt: Homogeneity Pursuit in Regression Analysis: Statistical Theory, Integer Optimization, and Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
The research project lies in a cross-disciplinary field that intersects statistics, operations research, and machine learning with a motivation to study unknown quantities and associated structures of the unknowns, referred to as homogeneity pursuit. The novelty of the statistical paradigm of homogeneity pursuit pertains to its capacity for simultaneous operation of parameter clustering and estimation in association analyses. The project expects to deliver new statistical tools to the hands of practitioners to generate new knowledge from data. The principal investigator will apply the developed methodology for the derivation of environmental exposure mixtures of toxic agents, DNA methylation integration in epigenetics, and survey questionnaire summarization in social sciences. The project also includes substantial educational initiatives involving graduate students and exposing trainees to state-of-the-art research in the topics related to the research activities. 

The project develops a new statistical framework for association analyses in which similar model parameters are fused into subgroups while being estimated. The developed methodology harnesses mixed integer programming (MIO) to extend the best-subset regularization to perform a simultaneous operation of parameter clustering and estimation in regression analysis.  It also provides both analytic and algorithmic tools to improve the existing statistical solutions.  First, the project builds a new MIO formulation of simultaneous clustering and estimation for high-dimensional model parameters. The framework is flexible and efficient to fit a wide range of important statistical models, including generalized linear models (GLMs) for cross-sectional data, varying coefficient index models for nonlinear interactions, and mixed-effects models for longitudinal data. Second, to solve MIO problems, the project develops and implements a new fast and reliable algorithm, termed as Alternating Penalized Operator for L-zero Loss Optimization (APOLLO). Third, the project plans to establish both finite and large sample properties of the MIO estimator for group memberships and group parameters in GLMs and semiparametric models and investigate the theory of integer optimization to justify the MIO solver, APOLLO.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This proposal develops a new statistical paradigm that can perform a simultaneous operation of parameter clustering and estimation in regression analysis, which is referred to as homogeneity pursuit throughout this proposal.

Intellectual Merit

The research project lies in a cross-disciplinary field that intersects statistics, operational research, and machine learning with a motivation to study unknown quantities and associated structures of the unknowns, referred to as homogeneity pursuit. The novelty of the proposed statistical paradigm of homogeneity pursuit pertains to its capacity for simultaneous operation of parameter clustering and estimation in association analyses. The project delivers several new statistical tools that can potentially be used by practitioners to generate new knowledge from data. The principal investigator applies the proposed methodology for the derivation of environmental exposure mixtures of toxic agents, DNA methylation integration in epigenetics, selection of key manholes from wastewater systems in community surveillance of COVID-19 infection, and survey questionnaire summarization in social sciences. 

The project develops a new statistical framework for association analyses in which similar model parameters are fused into subgroups while being estimated. The proposed methodology harnesses mixed integer programming (MIO) to extend the best-subset regularization to perform a simultaneous operation of parameter clustering and estimation in regression analysis.  The developed methodology provides both analytic and algorithmic tools to improve the existing statistical solutions.  First, the project builds a new MIO formulation of simultaneous clustering and estimation for high-dimensional model parameters. The framework is flexible and efficient to fit a wide range of important statistical models. Second, to solve MIO problems, the project develops and implements a new fast and reliable algorithm, termed as Alternating Penalized Operator for L-zero Loss Optimization (APOLLO). Third, the project establishes both finite and large sample properties of the MIO estimator for group memberships and group parameters in GLMs, scalar-on-function models, and semiparametric models and investigate the theory of integer optimization to justify the proposed MIO solver, APOLLO. These results have been disseminated by peer-reviewed publications in both statistical journal and substantial science journals. 

 Broader Impact. 

The research and educational programs make significant contributions in several areas. The major contribution lies in developing a unified framework of powerful homogeneity pursuit methodology that enables a simultaneous operation of parameter clustering and estimation. The PI has close connections with researchers in other fields, Biology, Epidemiology, Environmental Health Sciences, Infectious Disease Surveillance, and Nutritional Sciences. He has been working closely with these subject-matter scientists who will serve as local users of the methodologies and provide valuable feedback. The PI disseminates the research results to these and other researchers in application areas.

The proposal also includes substantial educational initiatives involving graduate students and expose them to state-of-the-art research in the topics related to the proposal. These include new courses, summer workshops, mentoring, and software development. These and other dissemination activities increase awareness of modern powerful methods for data analysis among scientists from other fields.
